node.text:
Climate change has had a devastating impact on Nigeria. 

Fertile lands are turning into deserts in the north, while flash floods have become more common in the south.

Nigeria’s oil industry is making the situation worse, as the practice of flaring - the burning of natural gas that is released when oil is extracted from the ground - is common, despite being illegal, and is a major source of greenhouse gases and a contributor to climate change.

Joy and her family are among two million Nigerians living within 4km of a gas flare in the country’s oil-rich south.

#Nigeria #ClimateChange #BBCNews

node.title: The toxic gas flares fuelling Nigeria's climate change

Surf’s up! 🌊

Chinese youth, unable to travel overseas due to Covid restrictions, are increasingly flocking to local beaches to pick up surfing and ride the waves.

node.text:
In the wake of the 9/11 terror attacks, the US saw a sharp rise in hate crimes. The attackers targeted those they believed to be Arab Muslims.

The innocent victims included Balbir Singh Sodhi, an American-Sikh who had a beard and wore a turban and ran the family gas station in Mesa, Arizona.

His murder, four days after 9/11, was the first racially-motivated hate crime in the backlash of the attacks.

The BBC spoke to Balbir's brother, and for the first time, his son and the gunman.

#911 #US #BBCNews

node.title: 'My dad was killed in the first hate-crime after 9/11'

node.text:
"She was incredible and absolutely so beautiful."

In April, former footballer and reality TV star Ashley Cain and his partner, Safiyya Vorajee, lost their eight-month-old daughter Azaylia to leukaemia.

The couple told @ashleyjbaptiste about their experiences of dealing with grief and bereavement – and urged other people going through similar pain to "talk about it".

Ashley is currently riding 1,000 miles to raise more money for the childhood cancer foundation the couple launched.

If you, or someone you know, has been affected by this story you can get support, information and advice from BBC Action Line: https://www.bbc.co.uk/actionline/

#Leukaemia #BBCNews

node.title: Ashley Cain on baby daughter's death

node.text:
North Korea has announced it fired a new long-range cruise missile over the weekend.

Despite international condemnation, the East Asian country keeps testing missiles, some of which are in violation of UN Security Council resolutions and have resulted in tough sanctions.

So why does Pyongyang continue with these launches, if they come at such a hefty cost to its economy?

#NorthKorea #Pyongyang #BBCNews

node.title: Why does North Korea keep launching missiles?

node.text:
Stephanie, 13,  is concerned about the impact burning fossil fuels has on climate change. But her dad Andrew is a senior employee at BP and worked in the oil industry for more than 20 years.

Climate change is a hot topic at home.

She questions: “Does this mean he doesn’t care about my future? Does this mean by default that I don’t care about the planet?”

While Stephanie worries about the Earth's future, she hopes BP's sustainability commitments could make her dad part of the solution.

#ClimateChange #GlobalWarming #BBCNews

node.title: 'I care about climate change - but my dad works in the oil industry'

node.text:
Meet Guy Bellingham, who uses a 170-year-old technique to make striking photos in remarkable detail. 📷 
 
Guy is a wet plate photographer and his 'Victorian Polaroid' process uses various chemicals to produce pictures that have incredible clarity and detail.
 
Mr Bellingham says the resulting image feels “like you’re capturing people’s souls and immortalising them”.

#Photo #Photography #BBCNews

node.title: "It's like a ghost coming out of the mist."

node.text:
British tennis sensation Emma Raducanu has been speaking about how it felt to receive a compliment from Queen Elizabeth II after winning the US Open title.
 
In a statement, the Queen praised the 18-year-old’s “outstanding performance” and described her success as “a remarkable achievement… [that] will inspire the next generation of tennis players".
 
18-year-old Emma said she planned to celebrate beating teenager Leylah Fernandez with chocolate flavoured frozen yoghurt.

Tap the link in our bio to read more about Emma's reaction to her fairy tale win in New York.

#Tennis #BBCSport #BBCNews

node.title: “It meant everything to get a message from Her Majesty.”

node.text:
Twenty years after the deadliest attacks on US soil, those who died in the 9/11 attacks have been remembered across America.
 
The official memorial in New York started with a minute's silence at the exact moment the first plane hit the North Tower of the World Trade Center in 2001.
 
There were five more moments of silence over the next few hours - marking the time when the second plane crashed into the South Tower, when a third jet struck the Pentagon just outside Washington DC, when the fourth plane crashed in Pennsylvania, and finally when each tower collapsed.
 
Tap the link in our bio to read more about the commemorations.

#911 #September11 #BBCNews

node.title: Commemorations to mark the 20th anniversary of the 9/11 attacks.

node.text:
"I live in a camp, like every refugee."

The BBC first met Wahida Faizi, an Afghan journalist attempting to flee the Taliban, at Kabul airport in August.
In an emotional interview, she said she feared that the Taliban would kill her for the work she'd done in her career as a journalist. 
A few weeks on, Wahida told the BBC what life is like for her now.

#Afghanistan #BBC

node.text:
Days after the attacks on 11 September 2001, the internet was rife with fake claims of what happened on the day.

Many were quickly dismissed as silly hoaxes, but others were rooted in racism and anti-Semitism and conspiracies of collusion by the deep state.

Twenty years later they are a powerful reminder of how the internet can be manipulated to distort the truth.

#911 #September11 #BBCNews

node.text:
Climate change has had a devastating impact on Nigeria. 

Fertile lands are turning into deserts in the north, while flash floods have become more common in the south.

Nigeria’s oil industry is making the situation worse, as the practice of flaring - the burning of natural gas that is released when oil is extracted from the ground - is common, despite being illegal, and is a major source of greenhouse gases and a contributor to climate change.

Joy and her family are among two million Nigerians living within 4km of a gas flare in the country’s oil-rich south.

#Nigeria #ClimateChange #BBCNews

node.text:
Surf’s up! 🌊

Chinese youth, unable to travel overseas due to Covid restrictions, are increasingly flocking to local beaches to pick up surfing and ride the waves.

#China #Surfing #Coronavirus #BBCNews

node.text:
Look at him go! 🚴🚴🚴  

Aspiring 12-year-old cyclist Xander sped past riders taking part in the Tour of Britain near Edinburgh, Scotland.
 
The decorated teenage amateur went to watch riders on the seventh stage of the race near his home.  

In a spur of the moment decision he hopped on his bike and starting "riding as fast as I could - about 25km an hour I think."  

He plans to treasure the water bottle he was given by Pascal Eenkhoorn, part of the Netherlands team.  

Tap the link in our bio to read more his hopes and dreams in the saddle.  

(📷 SWPix)  

#Cycling #Scotland #BBCNews

node.text:
Kim Kardashian rocked up at the Met Gala in an all-black outfit that shocked and confused fans, while singer Frank Ocean brought a green robot baby as a date.
 
Meanwhile, congresswoman Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez made a statement with a dress that said “Tax the rich” on the back.
 
These were just some of the most memorable looks on the red carpet at fashion's biggest event, which has returned after being delayed for a year due to the pandemic. 

And although its famous guests must still follow Covid-19 rules, including wearing masks indoors and be fully vaccinated, that hasn't stopped many going for all-out glamour.
 
This year's costume theme is "In America: A Lexicon of Fashion", and the looks were inspired by everything from the Matrix film franchise to the Statue of Liberty.

Tap the link in our bio for more weird and wonderful outfits. 

Pic 1: Kim Kardashian
Pic 2: Frank Ocean
Pic 3: Kim Petras
Pic 4: A$AP Rocky and Rihanna
Pic 5: Timothée Chalamet
Pic 6: Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez
Pic 7: Billie Eilish 
Pic 8: Naomi Osaka
Pic 9: Amanda Gorman

(📸: Getty Images)

#MetGala #Fashion #BBCNews

node.text:
In the wake of the 9/11 terror attacks, the US saw a sharp rise in hate crimes. The attackers targeted those they believed to be Arab Muslims.

The innocent victims included Balbir Singh Sodhi, an American-Sikh who had a beard and wore a turban and ran the family gas station in Mesa, Arizona.

His murder, four days after 9/11, was the first racially-motivated hate crime in the backlash of the attacks.

The BBC spoke to Balbir's brother, and for the first time, his son and the gunman.

#911 #US #BBCNews

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by BBC News on September 13, 2021. May be an image of outdoors and monument.

node.text:
The dream of an artist who died last year has been fulfilled in Paris.

Giants sheets of fabric have been draped down the Arc de Triomphe in tribute to Bulgarian-born artist Christo, who passed away in May 2020.

Known for wrapping famous landmarks in fabric, Christo had dreamed of sheathing the 50m-high monument since renting a nearby apartment in the 1960s.

His vision has finally been brought to life by Christo's nephew, Vladimir Javacheff, at a cost of about €14m (£11.9m; $16.54m).

Tap the link in our bio to see more pictures of the sheets adorning the monument.

(📷 EPA, Getty Images)

#Paris #ArcDeTriomphe #Art #BBCNews

node.text:
"She was incredible and absolutely so beautiful."

In April, former footballer and reality TV star Ashley Cain and his partner, Safiyya Vorajee, lost their eight-month-old daughter Azaylia to leukaemia.

The couple told @ashleyjbaptiste about their experiences of dealing with grief and bereavement – and urged other people going through similar pain to "talk about it".

Ashley is currently riding 1,000 miles to raise more money for the childhood cancer foundation the couple launched.

If you, or someone you know, has been affected by this story you can get support, information and advice from BBC Action Line: https://www.bbc.co.uk/actionline/

#Leukaemia #BBCNews

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by BBC News on September 13, 2021. May be an image of text.

node.text:
These striking night-time shots of wildlife in an English garden were captured with a motion-activated remote camera.

Ola Maddams had previously taken pictures of lions, leopards and elephants in Kenya – but during lockdown in 2020 she decided to focus on her own garden in Buckinghamshire.

She told us she is fascinated by the way remote cameras can capture animals "at their most natural and relaxed".

"We learned that just like humans, hedgehogs and foxes are creatures of habit, showing up in our garden at specific times and following certain routines," Mrs Maddams said.

She also tried her luck with her in her local woods and was rewarded with a badger and a roe deer.

Tap the link in our bio for more images and read more about Mrs Maddams photography.

(📷 Ola Maddams @olamaddams) 

#Wildlife #WildLifePhotography #Animals #Hedgehogs #Foxes #England #BBCNews

node.text:
North Korea has announced it fired a new long-range cruise missile over the weekend.

Despite international condemnation, the East Asian country keeps testing missiles, some of which are in violation of UN Security Council resolutions and have resulted in tough sanctions.

So why does Pyongyang continue with these launches, if they come at such a hefty cost to its economy?

#NorthKorea #Pyongyang #BBCNews

node.text:
Stephanie, 13,  is concerned about the impact burning fossil fuels has on climate change. But her dad Andrew is a senior employee at BP and worked in the oil industry for more than 20 years.

Climate change is a hot topic at home.

She questions: “Does this mean he doesn’t care about my future? Does this mean by default that I don’t care about the planet?”

While Stephanie worries about the Earth's future, she hopes BP's sustainability commitments could make her dad part of the solution.

#ClimateChange #GlobalWarming #BBCNews

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by BBC News on September 12, 2021. May be an image of 2 people and text that says 'NEWS Britney Spears announces engagement to Sam Asghari'.

node.text:
Britney Spears is engaged! 💍

In a surprise Instagram post, the pop star showed off her ring to her long-term boyfriend Sam Asghari.

Asghari, who is a personal trainer and actor, posted a separate photo of the ring and the couple kissing.

The two met on the set of a music video in 2016.

Spears is fighting a legal battle to end her 13-year conservatorship, which had her father controlling her life and finances. She revealed that the terms of the arrangement were preventing her from marrying Mr Asghari or having more children.
 
Tap the link in our bio for more on this story.

(📸: Getty Images)

#BritneySpears #Engagement #BBCNews
